intro: Lupinus lyallii var. lobbii, commonly known as Lyall’s lupine, is a flowering plant native to the Pacific Northwest of North America. It is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its tall, erect growth habit and clusters of blue to purple pea-shaped flowers. The plant has compound leaves composed of several oval-shaped leaflets and produces cylindrical pods that contain several seeds. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in open, sunny habitats such as meadows and rocky slopes. This variety is notable for its ornamental value and its role in nitrogen fixation, which benefits the surrounding ecosystem.
